author: Ben Rossington
title: Tesco short-changing customers by offering multi-buy deals that aren't applied at the tills
text:
Tesco says it will double check prices at all of its 3,500 stores (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing! Could   
Tesco has vowed to check the price of every item in its 3,500 UK stores after a probe found customers were being short-changed. 
Secret cameras discovered that in two-thirds of outlets investigated,­ items marked on offer did not have the discounts applied at the till. 
Investigators found multi-buy­ deals advertised days, weeks and, in one case, a month after the deductions were no longer being applied at the check-out. 
Some items went through tills at 60% more than the advertised offer price, others were nearly double. In every case when prompted about the discrepancy, Tesco staff honoured the offer. 
But Martin Fisher, of the Chartered Trading Standards Institute, said: “If customer A has come back and complained and been refunded, it could still mean 20 others didn’t spot it and so didn’t complain.” 
Even after the issue was highlighted at tills, some stores failed to remove out-of-date labels on the shelves, it was claimed. Read More Tesco to boost Clubcard points for current account customers - but here's how EVERYONE can reap the rewards The BBC went to 50 stores across the country (Photo: Getty) 
In the worst case, staff at a Tesco Express in Birmingham repeatedly failed to remove labels showing produce as on offer when it no longer was. It was still on display a month after it was first pointed out. 
Mr Fisher added: “That is very bad. It’s pretty basic that if one customer has shown something wrong then it’s put right to stop other customers being misled. Alarm bells would be ringing.” Read More 
The BBC investigation went to 50 stores across the country and found problems at 33, including in the West Midlands, Liverpool and Leeds. Tesco, Britain’s­ biggest supermarket chain, already employs teams to ensure prices are up to date. 
But it has now promised to double-check the prices of all stock at its 3,500 UK stores. 
A spokesman said: “We take great care to deliver clear and accurate labels for our cust­­omers, so they can make informed decisions on the products­ they buy. 
“We are disappointed errors occurred and will work with stores involved to reinforce­ our responsibilities to customers”. Inside Out, tonight, 7.30pm, on BBC One Like us on Facebook
